comments.commentBody: We also need to ask "are there enough school seats in this neighborhood to serve children in these new buildings?"  The Bloomberg adm. literally left out any consideration of school seats in its 2030 plan!  From that we extrapolate that he expects families with school-age children to leave the city for the suburbs.  Literally: "if we don't build schools, they'll go away."  Only young, high-paid workers are wanted.  Meanwhile, if Manhattan is in such demand, what's with all   "ghost" condos -- new buildings perennially half-dark at night?  Speaking of ghost real estate, before building any more new buildings, why not declare eminent domain and make habitable all those buildings empty above the street level in East Harlem written about in the Times a few months ago?   Who's waiting for what over there?
His season is probably over -- and maybe even his career
David, I thought the same...just shows you can be right for the wrong reason!

Couldn't have done this without google, but even so some of the entries were just awful: 9D didn't sink in until long after, and I never heard of 1A and 12D. Eh bien ...

... but I do have a quibble!! The last letter of the fill for 57A should be M, not T. Think about it.

This is EXACTLY what must be done if we are to compete with the highest levels of soccer internationally. When I was 16, I spent a summer in London after a tournament training with a development squad run through Arsenal's youth academy and I was woefully lacking in technical ability compared to my European counterparts. By a mile. And I started on a team that went on to win the Illinois soccer state title my senior year and won tournaments in different parts of the country, so I played at among the highest non-collegiate levels here. It's nothing compared to Europe. The scholastic teams (and the majority of youth leagues) are more concerned with the success of the team, and to a lesser extent having fun, than player development. In the major European academies, keeping score is seldom done. The emphasis is on technical training and building skills to one day play for club and country, not fielding a team that wins some kind of "Tournament of Academies."

Honestly, this program makes all the sense in the world and I cannot comprehend any of it's critics. The "let the kids play" and "this hurts the school programs" miss the point entirely. This is what kids who want a shot to play at the elite levels want to do, I would have done anything for a shot at this. The idea that only a few kids will rise up and make it is exactly the point, creating truly elite players. Describing High Schools in the US as "inadequate" for molding top-level players is 100% accurate.
welcome home. Howie

There does seem to be an underlying pathology to the (R) -- a disdain for anyone but themselves (see: Gingrich; Cantor; Trump...), a need to control other people's lives (see: Walker; Brewer; McDonnell), a desire to please those who hold the pursestrings (see: Romney; Cain; Boehner), a deeply-rooted anger that seems shame-based (see: Limbaugh; Rove;), and an ambition that seems entirely self-directed (see: Palin; Trump; Beck)

Every society has flaws, but there's no need to reward the members who exemplify the problems (too many to be named), rather than the promise (see: Warren; Gillibrand; DeLauro... and, of course, the President and his family).

The answer is: No. He has no shame.

Just read his "apology." He is a lame, cowardly, loud-mouthed, ignorant gasbag.

And he has a million followers on Facebook.

The GOP must have a master plan that includes moving so far to the insane right of American society that they can't help but lose in November. Then the centrist, Rwing of the GOP (if there is such a thing anymore) can begin to take back the party in time for the 2016 elections. Otherwise, I can't think of any good reason why they are spouting the utter nonsense and mysogynistic garbage we've seen over the last few months. Or maybe they are looking to win the election of 1928 all over again? Who knows?!

Make note of the advertisers  & boycott them , don't let up, keep track of any new  advertisers & boycott them.  E-mail them & tell them why, we all have access to computers to do this This is where our real power lies .Limbaugh will be forced to react appropriately MONEY TALKS .
As to Limbaugh, to borrow a phrase from Barry Goldwater, every good American should kick Rush in the ___ .

Today's GOP comes by misogyny the old fashioned way- by reactionary religion.  The flap over contraception, sex, and the rest is one small battle in their war to defeat modernity.  They may put women in bikinis rather than burkas, but they treat them as objects or property just the same.  Now if they could just get the vote away from them...

What is even more appalling than his remarks is the fact that he "apologizes" by posting to his web site. His "apology" is insincere in every respect.
All of us who had to view his disgusting remarks as they were broadcast were offended in ways in which words are insufficient to describe the societal hiorror of hearing this 4 time married, obese and grotesque characature of a person give his hateful opinions. It was no joke. he did not intend it as a joke. He is immoral to the max.
Posters are correct - Ms.Fluke should sue him, the radio station and the remaining sponsors. Many people I know have said they will support (and shop) at Sleep Train and any sponsor who yanked their support.
He is scary, hateful, mean and probably dysfunctional "at home." How many wives do he and Newt need?

Even in an apology, RL still comes across as sanctimonious and wrong.

In his posting, he lumps everything under "social activities." Really? If we stick strictly to married couples, marital intimacy is not what most would call social activates. No one I know is likely to call a caterer and invite the neighbors over for appetizers and to watch. And just married couples? While we may talk openly about extra-marital sex over the past few decades more freely, it has occurred for as long as humans have been coupling monogamously.

Second, not all contraception is about birth control. Some is about health. Birth control pills are used to help women with menstrual problems and more. Condoms can prevent the spread of disease. If a man has an infection and wants to avoid spreading it to his wife - oh wait, having intercourse then would be sinful, right?

As a man, I cannot help but marvel at how many men (with the power of the pulpit, their birthright, or their economic position) have treated women as property and as their version of a puppy farm. Funny how little they like it when the women folk get all no sirree on them.

Lastly, while this does need to be called out, is RL really worth a Sunday column, Maureen?
Maureen, you're tiptoeing into a knife fight armed with a bouquet of rational rebuttals.  You can be tougher than that.  Give the guy what he deserves, a full-throated condemnation.

"... Rush Limbaugh...cult entertainer..."

well said...

I haven't listened to Rush Limbaugh in a lot of years, but has he developed any kind of credibility as anything other than a cult entertainer?
I never found him to be entertaining.

Steve Bonomo Jr of Illinois says, "I guess free contraception is another right. But it seems that for one group to have this new right, someone else's rights are diminished."

Oka-a-a-a-ay. Someone else's rights are diminished how?

I have a few ideas I wouldn't want to attribute to you. So I won't. Tell us whose rights are diminished.

Except for the sperm, and you might even be able to come up with some colorful justifiably for the egg, what is this "right" inhibiting. Or confounding.

Or is it the old canard: Birth control is alright as long it doesn't affect the sperm or the egg.
I'm an independent, but if I were a Democrat I would be thinking, "Thank you, Rush, for helping out our party!" Then I'd shake his hand.

Rush "apologized" only after sponsors abandoned him over his vile remarks. He's more sorry about the financial fallout than anything else. His comments combined with Santorum's medieval outbursts and Romney's cowardly silence beg a larger question: Why are Republicans and their conservative masters so uptight and repressive when it comes to women having sex? It's a losing electoral position as a Republican operative recently admitted to Maureen. Women are more than half the population and maybe more than half of the electorate. If nothing else, the Republican opposition to women having sex and taking proper precautions when doing so, is just bad retail politics. Maybe Republican men are just bad lovers...

I would love to see her sue this man.
Hypocrisy incarnate.
When you take down all the mirrors in your house, the spittle aimed at yourself has to hit something else.
Ah, but he does. Especially if that enables a Democrat President and a fully Democrat Congress and sends the whole religious loony bin running into the woods.
He is running the Republican Party- it is definitely time for a separation of Rush and State.
Let sleeping dogs lie! I wouldn't even waste my time giving Rush Limbag any attention. He doesn't deserve to be mentioned  in a paper as esteemed as the NY Times.

Congratulations, Maureen, from someone who was a lifelong Republican of the fiscal conservative variety until this year, when the party went insane, but fortunately there is nothing wrong with it which a royal drubbing at the ballot box won't cure, and it is certainly setting themselves up for one. The discomfort of Boehner, Romney and Santorum is hilarious. I feel sorry for whoever becomes the Republican nominee - with friends like Limbaugh who needs enemies ?

I suppose Rush and others, possibly you, believe that romantic encounters should in no way be pleasant -- or, gosh forbid, "recreational"?
I guess all encounter should only occur for procreational purposes?
Sounds like a LOT fewer Viagra opportunities to me.

Dlud, taxpayers are not expected to pay for women's birth control. Tax money doesn't go for health insurance. Dont you have health insurance? Dont you pay exhorbitant permiums like most Americans with health insurance do? Or are you on Medicare, which of course doesn't cover contraceptives since we oldsters are not going to get pregnant when we have our "personal sexual recreational sex".

Women's health insurers are expected to cover women's contraceptives and the regular gynecological care they require, and most do. The issue is that Georgetown refused to allow their insurer to cover contraceptives, and it appears they did so even in cases where the pill was desperately needed to treat ovarian cysts.

Is it that neither you nor Limnbaugh have sex for "personal sexual recreation"? You must be either celibate or only look upon sex as a boring chore? Is there such thing as sex that isn't "recreational"? Is there such thing as sex that isn't "personal" Do you expect a 30 year old woman to not have a boyfriend?

Do you believe students should all be celibate just as Santorum believes all members of the armed forces should be celibate?

You know, male condoms are cheap and readily available. Birth control is the responsibility of both parties engaging in sex and not wanting a child or more children than they already have. If men took on their share of the responsibility we wouldn't have this conversation.

I have noticed that Americans seem to revel in antagonism against some group or another that might benefit from their hard-earned tax dollars. Canadians seem to be more concerned with the welfare of the public at large and don't seem to be particularly preoccupied with finding some group that is somehow undeserving of the benefits of public policies and institutions -  e.g., Canadians cherish a health care system that is more concerned with health and less involved in passing glib moral judgments on the practices of some targeted group of individuals. Maybe that's because Canadians realize that someday they might be a member of one of those targeted groups, or maybe one of their kids might become a member of one of those groups, or the kid next door, or someone they know up the street, or maybe someone they don't even know who still somehow manages to carry some small spark of humanity. RE: paying for recreational drugs - check out the literature on prescribed heroin - we can pay to treat addicts effectively or we can pay to police and jail a class of dealers, but we are going to pay. A little less narcissistic overinvolvement in moralizing and a little more reality orientation might enlighten a political discourse that people like Limbaugh and institutions like Fox news are dragging back to the dark ages, via an extended layover in fantasy land.

I have no allegiance to Limbaugh and his political positions, but his comment about expecting taxpayers to pay for "personal sexual recreation" through health insurance - for students - was perfect.  We have become a society blinded by worship of all things sexual (and narcissistic). Or should we be paying for recreational drugs as well?

Rush Limbaugh has never been anything but a vicious bully, insulting & ridiculing the unfortunate in order to stoke the egos of the fortunate.  30 years ago his vulgarity was shocking, but now hundreds of imitators, Fox news, and most of the Republican party have jumped on the bandwagon.  They are all beneath contempt, but I'm most upset by the rest of us, whatever our politics, for keeping silent while these insane people took over our public life.  Why does the NY Times repeat the hoaxes started by Mr. Breitbart, for example, & publish fawning celebrity profiles of LImbaugh & Coulter & Beck?  Why do honest people appear on Fox news?  Just because demogaguery has proven to be so lucrative doesn't mean we have to pretend that the demagogues are engaging us in honest conversation.

I hope the decent Republicans rebuke Rush too, but I heard both of them are busy this weekend, so don't hold your breath. I've been waiting years to hear even a hint of conservative pushback against Limbaugh and there hasn't been a peep.
Rob P
http://cfdemsblog.com
